meta.title: deb-dl.org - Easy Debian Downloads
meta.description: The easiest way to download Debian ISOs - Netinstall, Live, Non-free firmware editions

hero.title: Download Debian the Easy Way
hero.subtitle: No more confusion. Get your Debian ISO in seconds.
hero.scrollHint: üëá Scroll down to see all available downloads

netinstall.title: Netinstall Images
netinstall.description: Minimal installation images. Downloads packages from the internet during installation.

nonfree.title: Non-free Firmware Images
nonfree.description: Includes proprietary firmware for better hardware compatibility (WiFi, GPU, etc.)

live.title: Live Images
live.description: Try Debian without installing. Boot from USB and test it first!

netboot.title: Network Boot Images
netboot.description: Boot and install Debian over the network (PXE). Browse the directory to find netboot.tar.gz and related files.

liveNonfree.title: Live Images + Non-free Firmware
liveNonfree.description: Live images with proprietary drivers for better hardware support

daily.title: Daily Builds & Testing
daily.description: Latest development builds. Use at your own risk!

footer.disclaimer: This is an unofficial mirror site. Official downloads at

step1.title: Step 1: Choose Your ISO
step1.description: For beginners, we recommend the Debian Live GNOME with non-free firmware. It includes all necessary drivers for laptops and modern hardware.

step2.title: Step 2: Create Bootable USB with Rufus
step2.description: Rufus is a free tool to create a bootable USB drive from your ISO file.
step2.downloadDesc: Get it from the official website
step2.insertDesc: At least 4GB. All data will be erased!
step2.selectISO: Click SELECT and choose your Debian ISO
step2.ddModeDesc: When asked, select "Write in DD Image mode" for Debian
step2.waitDesc: It may take 5-15 minutes depending on your USB speed

step3.title: Step 3: Boot from USB
step3.description: Now you need to tell your computer to start from the USB drive instead of your hard disk.
step3.restartDesc: Keep the USB drive plugged in
step3.selectUSBDesc: Choose your USB drive from the boot menu (might be labeled as "USB-HDD", "UEFI", or by brand name)
step3.enjoyDesc: Debian should now boot. You can try it live or proceed with installation.
